Description: Unique identifier of the broader project under which data were collected.

Particle size-integrated streamwise sediment mass flux. Values represent the mass of sediment transported per meter width through a surface-normal plane of infinite height per unit time and are reported in units of g∑m-1d-1.
Total mass of vertical dust emission for sediments = 20 µm diameter into the lower boundary layer per unit area of surface per unit time reported in g∑m-2d-1.
Total mass of vertical dust emission for sediments = 1 µm diameter into the lower boundary layer per unit area of surface per unit time reported in g∑m-2d-1.
Total mass of vertical dust emission for sediments = 2.5 µm diameter into the lower boundary layer per unit area of surface per unit time reported in g∑m-2d-1.
Total mass of vertical dust emission for sediments = 10 µm†diameter into the lower boundary layer per unit area of surface per unit time reported in g∑m-2d-1.
Parameter set ID for AERO model estimates of horizontal and vertical sediment flux. Possible values are 1ñ453.

Cumulative probability (CDF) values for each of 453 horizontal_flux_total estimates produced by AERO model. To produce CDFS for vertical_flux, PM1, PM2_5, and PM10 estimates, the following steps are needed: sort flux estimates and likelihoods by the flux category of interest; convert cumulative probabilities to difference between successive values; cumulatively sum likelihoods to produce CDF values for flux category of interest. In most cases, however, the rank order of all flux categories will be the same as horizontal_flux_total.
Model run identifier that notes the data and model instances run

Lower prediction interval (0.05 quantile of flux CDF) for single horizontal flux estimate reported in units of g∑m-1d-1.
Upper prediction interval (0.95 quantile of Flux CDF) for single horizontal flux estimate reported in units of g∑m-1d-1.
Median horizontal flux estimate from flux CDF produced by AERO model. This is the value reported when a single flux estimate is desired and is reported in units of g∑m-1d-1.

Estimated sample mean from horizontal flux prediction CDF. Can be used with horizontal_flux_total_STD to produce an estimated PDF of flux at a site. Flux is lognormally distributed. Thus, the sample mean and standard deviation estimates must first be used to calculate µ and s parameters of a lognormal distribution. Reported in units of g∑m-1d-1.

Estimated sample standard deviation from horizontal flux prediction CDF. Can be used with horizontal_flux_total_MN to produce an estimated PDF of flux at a site. Flux is lognormally distributed. Thus, the sample mean and standard deviation estimates must first be used to calculate µ and s parameters of a lognormal distribution. Reported in units of g∑m-1d-1.
Lower prediction interval (0.05 quantile of flux CDF) for single vertical flux estimate reported in g∑m-2d-1.
Upper prediction interval (0.95 quantile of flux CDF) for single vertical flux estimate reported in g∑m-2d-1.
Median vertical flux estimate from flux CDF produced by AERO model. This is the value reported when a single flux estimate is desired and is reported in g∑m-2d-1.

Estimated sample mean from horizontal flux prediction CDF. Can be used with vertical_flux_STD to produce an estimated PDF of flux at a site. Flux is lognormally distributed. Thus, the sample mean and standard deviation estimates must first be used to calculate µ and s parameters of a lognormal distribution. Reported in g∑m-2d-1.

Estimated sample standard deviation from vertical flux prediction CDF. Can be used with vertical_flux_MN to produce an estimated PDF of flux at a site. Flux is lognormally distributed. Thus, the sample mean and standard deviation estimates must first be used to calculate µ and s parameters of a lognormal distribution. Reported in g∑m-2d-1.
Lower prediction interval (0.05 quantile of flux CDF) for single PM1 flux estimate reported in g∑m-2d-1.
Upper prediction interval (0.95 quantile of flux CDF) for single PM1 flux estimate reported in g∑m-2d-1.
Median PM1 flux estimate from flux CDF produced by AERO model. This is the value reported when a single flux estimate is desired. Reported in g∑m-2d-1.

Estimated sample mean from PM1 prediction CDF. Can be used with PM1_STD to produce an estimated PDF of flux at a site. Flux is lognormally distributed. Thus, the sample mean and standard deviation estimates must first be used to calculate µ and s parameters of a lognormal distribution. Reported in g∑m-2d-1.

Estimated sample standard deviation from PM1 flux prediction CDF. Can be used with PM1_MN to produce an estimated PDF of flux at a site. Flux is lognormally distributed. Thus, the sample mean and standard deviation estimates must first be used to calculate µ and s parameters of a lognormal distribution. Reported in g∑m-2d-1.
Lower prediction interval (0.05 quantile of flux CDF) for single PM2.5 flux estimate reported in g∑m-2d-1.
Upper prediction interval (0.95 quantile of flux CDF) for single PM2.5 flux estimate reported in g∑m-2d-1.
Median PM2.5 flux estimate from flux CDF produced by AERO model. This is the value reported when a single flux estimate is desired. Reported in g∑m-2d-1.

Estimated sample mean from PM2.5 prediction CDF. Can be used with PM2_5_STD to produce an estimated PDF of flux at a site. Flux is lognormally distributed. Thus, the sample mean and standard deviation estimates must first be used to calculate µ and s parameters of a lognormal distribution. Reported in g∑m-2d-1.

Estimated sample standard deviation from PM2.5 prediction CDF. Can be used with PM2_5_MN to produce an estimated PDF of flux at a site. Flux is lognormally distributed. Thus, the sample mean and standard deviation estimates must first be used to calculate µ and s parameters of a lognormal distribution. Reported in g∑m-2d-1.
Lower prediction interval (0.05 quantile of flux CDF) for single PM10 flux estimate. Reported in g∑m-2d-1.
Upper prediction interval (0.95 quantile of flux CDF) for single PM10 flux estimate. Reported in g∑m-2d-1.
Median PM10 flux estimate from flux CDF produced by AERO model. This is the value reported when a single flux estimate is desired. Reported in g∑m-2d-1.

Estimated sample mean from PM10 flux prediction CDF. Can be used with PM10_STD to produce an estimated PDF of flux at a site. Flux is lognormally distributed. Thus, the sample mean and standard deviation estimates must first be used to calculate µ and s parameters of a lognormal distribution. Reported in g∑m-2d-1.

Estimated sample standard deviation from PM10 flux prediction CDF. Can be used with PM10_MN to produce an estimated PDF of flux at a site. Flux is lognormally distributed. Thus, the sample mean and standard deviation estimates must first be used to calculate µ and s parameters of a lognormal distribution. Reported in g∑m-2d-1.

Describes if AERO has been run at the plot and if not, the reason AERO data is unavailable for the plot. Potential options are: 1: AERO not yet run 
2: Insufficient AERO inputs 3: AERO attempted, run unsuccessful
4: AERO run successful 
5: AERO development data, AERO not run

Alias: Percent of plot covered by Ecological Site
Description: Percent of plot covered by Ecological Site.
The latitude of the plot location in NAD83 datum. If Location Status = Private this is a fuzzed coordiNAte.
The longitude of the plot location in NAD83 datum. If LocationStatus = Private this is a fuzzed coordiNAte.
Notes whether a location if public or private. If private, Latitude_NAD83 and Longitude_NAD83 will be fuzzed coordiNAtes.
Coordinate type, Field (actual) or Target (GPS) location for plot.
The measured latitude of the plot location in NAD83 datum regardless of LocationStatus.
The measured longitude of the plot location in NAD83 datum regardless of LocationStatus.

The percent of ground, not covered by foliar or basal plants, rock fragments, biological crusts, or litter. For example, points with sagebrush over bare soil are not counted in this indicator, also points with rock as the soil surface code are not counted in this indicator. This indicator is derived from the Line-point Intercept method.
The percent total foliar cover of plants in the plot. This indicator is derived from the Line-point Intercept method.
The percent foliar cover of annual grasses in the plot. This indicator is derived from the Line-point Intercept method.
The percent foliar cover of forbs in the plot. This indicator is derived from the Line-point Intercept method.
The percent foliar cover of grasses in the plot. This indicator is derived from the Line-point Intercept method.
The percent foliar cover of perennial forbs in the plot. This indicator is derived from the Line-point Intercept method.

Alias: Perennial Forb and Grass Cover (% Any Hit)
Description: The percent foliar cover of perennial grasses and forbs in the plot. This indicator is derived from the Line-point Intercept method.
The percent foliar cover of perennial grasses in the plot. This indicator is derived from the Line-point Intercept method.
The percent foliar cover of shrubs in the plot. This indicator is derived from the Line-point Intercept method.

The percent cover of cyanobacterial crust (first hit) in the plot, not including cyanobacterial crust that has cover above it. For example, points with sagebrush over biological crust are not counted in this indicator. This indicator is derived from the Line-point Intercept method.

The percent cover of deposited soil (first hit) in the plot, not including deposited soil that has cover above it. For example, points with sagebrush over deposited soil are not counted in this indicator. This indicator is derived from the Line-point Intercept method.

The percent cover of duff (first hit) in the plot, not including duff that has cover above them. For example, points with sagebrush over duff are not counted in this indicator. This indicator is derived from the Line-point Intercept method.

The percent cover of embedded litter (first hit) in the plot, not including embedded litter that has cover above it. For example, points with sagebrush over embedded litter are not counted in this indicator. This indicator is derived from the Line-point Intercept method.

The percent cover of herbaceous litter (first hit) in the plot, not including herbaceous litter that has cover above it. For example, points with sagebrush over herbaceous litter are not counted in this indicator. This indicator is derived from the Line-point Intercept method.

The percent cover of lichens (first hit) in the plot, not including lichens that have cover above them. For example, points with sagebrush over lichen are not counted in this indicator. This indicator is derived from the Line-point Intercept method.

The percent cover of mosses (first hit) in the plot, not including mosses that have cover above them. For example, points with sagebrush over moss are not counted in this indicator. This indicator is derived from the Line-point Intercept method.

The percent cover (first hit) of rock (i.e., rock, boulder, cobble, gravel, bedrock, and stone) in the plot, not including rock that has cover above it. For example, points with sagebrush over rock are not counted in this indicator. This indicator is derived from the Line-point Intercept method.

The percent cover of total litter (first hit), both herbaceous and woody, in the plot, not including litter that has cover above it. For example, points with sagebrush over litter are not counted in this indicator. This indicator is derived from the Line-point Intercept method.

The percent cover of vagrant lichen (first hit) in the plot, not including vagrant lichen that has cover above it. For example, points with sagebrush over vagrant lichen are not counted in this indicator. This indicator is derived from the Line-point Intercept method.

The percent cover of water (first hit) in the plot, not including water that has cover above it. For example, points with perennial grass over water are not counted in this indicator. This indicator is derived from the Line-point Intercept method.

The percent cover of woody litter (first hit) in the plot, not including woody litter that has cover above it. For example, points with sagebrush over woody litter are not counted in this indicator. This indicator is derived from the Line-point Intercept method.
The percentage of the plot's soil surface covered by gaps between plant canopies that are from 101-200 cm in size. This indicator is derived from the Gap Intercept method.
The percentage of the plot's soil surface covered by gaps between plant canopies that are greater than 200 cm in size. This indicator is derived from the Gap Intercept method.

Alias: Canopy Gap greater than 25 to 50 cm (%)
Description: The percentage of the plot's soil surface covered by gaps between plant canopies that are from 25-50 cm in size. This indicator is derived from the Gap Intercept method.
The percentage of the plot's soil surface covered by gaps between plant canopies that are greater than 25 cm in size. This indicator is derived from the Gap Intercept method.
The percentage of the plot's soil surface covered by gaps between plant canopies that are from 51-100 cm in size. This indicator is derived from the Gap Intercept method.

Average height in cm of forbs in the plot. This indicator is derived from the Vegetation Height method. Measurements will be dropped in any instance where a species was measured as a Non-woody height but the code in the species list is a Woody species. Heights where a species code was recorded but the height = 0 are not included in the height calculations.

Average height in cm of grasses in the plot. This indicator is derived from the Vegetation Height method. Measurements will be dropped in any instance where a species was measured as a Non-woody height but the code in the species list is a Woody species. Heights where a species code was recorded but the height = 0 are not included in the height calculations.

Average height in cm of herbaceous plants in the plot. This indicator is derived from the Vegetation Height method. Measurements will be dropped in any instance where a species was measured as a Non-woody height but the code in the species list is a Woody species. Heights where a species code was recorded but the height = 0 are not included in the height calculations.

Average height in cm of perennial forbs in the plot. This indicator is derived from the Vegetation Height method. Measurements will be dropped in any instance where a species was measured as a Non-woody height but the code in the species list is a Woody species. Heights where a species code was recorded but the height = 0 are not included in the height calculations.

Alias: Average Perennial Forb and Grass Height (cm)
Description: Average height in cm of perennial forbs and grasses in the plot. This indicator is derived from the Vegetation Height method. Measurements will be dropped in any instance where a species was measured as a Non-woody height but the code in the species list is a Woody species. Heights where a species code was recorded but the height = 0 are not included in the height calculations.

Average height in cm of perennial grasses in the plot. This indictor is derived from the Vegetation Height method. Measurements will be dropped in any instance where a species was measured as a Non-woody height but the code in the species list is a Woody species. Heights where a species code was recorded but the height = 0 are not included in the height calculations.

Average height in cm of woody plants in the plot. This indicator is derived from the Vegetation Height method. Measurements will be dropped in any instance where a species was measured as a Woody height but the code in the species list is a Non-woody species. Heights where a species code was recorded but the height = 0 are not included in the height calculations.

Amount of total annual production as a departure from reference conditions. (NS = None to Slight; SM = Slight to Moderate; MO = Moderate; ME = Moderate to Extreme; ET = Extreme to Total). Based on Interpreting Indicators of Rangeland Health Technical Reference 1734-6 (https://www.landscapetoolbox.org/manuals/iirhv5/).

Degree of bare ground exposure departure from reference conditions. (NS = None to Slight; SM = Slight to Moderate; MO = Moderate; ME = Moderate to Extreme; ET = Extreme to Total). Based on Interpreting Indicators of Rangeland Health Technical Reference 1734-6 (https://www.landscapetoolbox.org/manuals/iirhv5/).

Rating of the Biotic Integrity attribute of rangeland health. Biotic integrity is defined as the capacity of the biotic community to support ecological processes within the normal range of variability expected for the site, to resist a loss in the capacity to support these processes, and to recover this capacity when losses do occur. The biotic community includes plants, animals, and microorganisms occurring both above and below ground. (NS = None to Slight; SM = Slight to Moderate; MO = Moderate; ME = Moderate to Extreme; ET = Extreme to Total). Based on Interpreting Indicators of Rangeland Health Technical Reference 1734-6 (https://www.landscapetoolbox.org/manuals/iirhv5/).

Comments regarding the Biotic Integrity attribute of rangeland health. Biotic integrity is defined as the capacity of the biotic community to support ecological processes within the normal range of variability expected for the site, to resist a loss in the capacity to support these processes, and to recover this capacity when losses do occur. The biotic community includes plants, animals, and microorganisms occurring both above and below ground.

Comments regarding the Hydrologic Function attribute of rangeland health. Hydrologic function is defined as the capacity of an area to capture, store, and safely release water from rainfall, run-on, and snowmelt (where relevant), to resist a reduction in this capacity, and to recover this capacity where a reduction does occur.

Alias: IIRH Soil and Site Stability Comments
Description: Comments regarding the Soil & Site Stability attribute of rangeland health. Soil & Site Stability is defined as the capacity of an area to limit redistribution and loss of soil resources (including nutrients and organic matter) by wind and water.

Presence or absence of a compaction layer, distribution of the layer, and density and thickness as a departure from reference conditions. (NS = None to Slight; SM = Slight to Moderate; MO = Moderate; ME = Moderate to Extreme; ET = Extreme to Total). Based on Interpreting Indicators of Rangeland Health Technical Reference 1734-6 (https://www.landscapetoolbox.org/manuals/iirhv5/).

Alias: IIRH Dead and Dying Plant Pars
Description: Degree of departure from reference state of proportion of dead or dying plants or plant parts. (NS = None to Slight; SM = Slight to Moderate; MO = Moderate; ME = Moderate to Extreme; ET = Extreme to Total). Based on Interpreting Indicators of Rangeland Health Technical Reference 1734-6 (https://www.landscapetoolbox.org/manuals/iirhv5/).

Degree of change of the functional/structural plant communities as a departure from reference conditions. (NS = None to Slight; SM = Slight to Moderate; MO =: Moderate; ME = Moderate to Extreme; ET = Extreme to Total). Based on Interpreting Indicators of Rangeland Health Technical Reference 1734-6 (https://www.landscapetoolbox.org/manuals/iirhv5/).

Degree of gully formation departure from reference conditions. (NS =: None to Slight; SM = Slight to Moderate; MO =: Moderate; ME = Moderate to Extreme; ET = Extreme to Total). Based on Interpreting Indicators of Rangeland Health Technical Reference 1734-6 (https://www.landscapetoolbox.org/manuals/iirhv5/).

Rating of the Hydrologic Function attribute of rangeland health. Hydrologic function is defined as the capacity of an area to capture, store, and safely release water from rainfall, run-on, and snowmelt (where relevant), to resist a reduction in this capacity, and to recover this capacity where a reduction does occur. (NS = None to Slight; SM = Slight to Moderate; MO = Moderate; ME = Moderate to Extreme; ET = Extreme to Total). Based on Interpreting Indicators of Rangeland Health Technical Reference 1734-6 (https://www.landscapetoolbox.org/manuals/iirhv5/).

Assessment of presence of invasive plants. (NS = None to Slight; SM = Slight to Moderate; MO = Moderate; ME = Moderate to Extreme; ET = Extreme to Total). Based on Interpreting Indicators of Rangeland Health Technical Reference 1734-6 (https://www.landscapetoolbox.org/manuals/iirhv5/).

Amount of herbaceous and woody litter present as a departure from reference conditions. (NS = None to Slight; SM = Slight to Moderate; MO =: Moderate; ME = Moderate to Extreme; ET =: Extreme to Total). Based on Interpreting Indicators of Rangeland Health Technical Reference 1734-6 (https://www.landscapetoolbox.org/manuals/iirhv5/).

Degree of litter movement due to water or wind as a departure from reference conditions. (NS = None to Slight; SM = Slight to Moderate; MO = Moderate; ME =: Moderate to Extreme; ET = Extreme to Total). Based on Interpreting Indicators of Rangeland Health Technical Reference 1734-6 (https://www.landscapetoolbox.org/manuals/iirhv5/).

Degree of erosional pedestal and terracette formation as a departure from reference conditions. (NS = None to Slight; SM = Slight to Moderate; MO = Moderate; ME = Moderate to Extreme; ET = Extreme to Total). Based on Interpreting Indicators of Rangeland Health Technical Reference 1734-6 (https://www.landscapetoolbox.org/manuals/iirhv5/).

Degree to which changes in functional/structural groups and their associated species composition and distribution have negatively affected infiltration or runoff as a departure from reference conditions. (NS = None to Slight; SM = Slight to Moderate; MO = Moderate; ME = Moderate to Extreme; ET = Extreme to Total). Based on Interpreting Indicators of Rangeland Health Technical Reference 1734-6 (https://www.landscapetoolbox.org/manuals/iirhv5/).

Alias: IIRH Reproductive Capability of Perennial Plants
Description: Degree to which the vigor or reproductive capability of noninvasive perennial plants has diminished relative to reference conditions. (NS = None to Slight; SM = Slight to Moderate; MO = Moderate; ME = Moderate to Extreme; ET = Extreme to Total). Based on Interpreting Indicators of Rangeland Health Technical Reference 1734-6 (https://www.landscapetoolbox.org/manuals/iirhv5/).

Degree of rill formation as a departure from reference conditions. (NS = None to Slight; SM = Slight to Moderate; MO = Moderate, ME = Moderate to Extreme; ET = Extreme to Total). Based on Interpreting Indicators of Rangeland Health Technical Reference 1734-6 (https://www.landscapetoolbox.org/manuals/iirhv5/).

Rating of the Soil & Site Stability attribute of rangeland health. Soil & Site Stability is defined as the capacity of an area to limit redistribution and loss of soil resources (including nutrients and organic matter) by wind and water. (NS = None to Slight; SM = Slight to Moderate; MO = Moderate; ME = Moderate to Extreme; ET = Extreme to Total). Based on Interpreting Indicators of Rangeland Health Technical Reference 1734-6(https://www.landscapetoolbox.org/manuals/iirhv5/).

Alias: IIRH Soil Surface Loss and Degredation
Description: Degree of soil surface loss and degradation from wind and water erosion as a departure from reference conditions. (NS = None to Slight; SM = Slight to Moderate; MO = Moderate; ME = Moderate to Extreme; ET = Extreme to Total). Based on Interpreting Indicators of Rangeland Health Technical Reference 1734-6 (https://www.landscapetoolbox.org/manuals/iirhv5/).

Alias: IIRH Soil Surface Resistance to Erosion
Description: Degree of reduced soil surface resistance to erosion as a departure from reference conditions. (NS = None to Slight; SM = Slight to Moderate; MO = Moderate; ME = Moderate to Extreme; ET = Extreme to Total). Based on Interpreting Indicators of Rangeland Health Technical Reference 1734-6 (https://www.landscapetoolbox.org/manuals/iirhv5/).

Degree of water flow patterns formation as a departure from reference conditions. (NS = None to Slight; SM = Slight to Moderate; MO = Moderate; ME = Moderate to Extreme; ET = Extreme to Total). Based on Interpreting Indicators of Rangeland Health Technical Reference 1734-6 (https://www.landscapetoolbox.org/manuals/iirhv5/).

Degree of wind scoured and depositional area and connectivity as a departure from reference conditions. (NS = None to Slight; SM =: Slight to Moderate; MO = Moderate; ME = Moderate to Extreme; ET = Extreme to Total). Based on Interpreting Indicators of Rangeland Health Technical Reference 1734-6 (https://www.landscapetoolbox.org/manuals/iirhv5/).

The average soil aggregate stability of all samples in the plot. This indicator is measured using the Soil Aggregate Stability method. In this test, stability ranges from 1-6, with 1 being the least stable and 6 being the most stable.

Alias: Average Soil Stability of Protected Surfaces
Description: The average soil aggregate stability of samples collected under with cover (Canopy or Grass, Tree, Shrub, Forb, Root Mat) in the plot. This indicator is measured using the Soil Aggregate Stability method. In this test, stability ranges from 1-6, with 1 being the least stable and 6 being the most stable.

Alias: Average Soil Stability of Unprotected Surfaces
Description: The average soil aggregate stability of samples collected between cover (e.g., with no cover directly above them) in the plot. This indicator is measured using the Soil Aggregate Stability method. In this test, stability ranges from 1-6, with 1 being the least stable and 6 being the most stable.

The plant species code found on a plot in the Species Inventory, Vegetation Height, or Line-point Intercept method.
Scientific name of the plant
The percent foliar cover of the species code found in the Species field in the plot. This indicator is derived from the Line-point Intercept method.
The count of hits of the species code found in the Species field in the plot. This indicator is derived from the Line-point Intercept method.
Average height in cm of the species code found in the Species field in the plot. This indicator is derived from the Vegetation Height method.

Alias: N of Height Measurements of Species
Description: The count of measurements that were used to calculate the Hgt_Species_Avg. Measurements will be dropped in any instance where a species was measured as a Non-woody or Woody height but the code in the species list is the opposite Growth Habit (Woody or Non-woody). Heights where a species code was recorded but the height = 0 are not included in the height calculations.

The life length of a plant. This field contains either Perennial or Annual with Biennial plants classified as Annuals. The most common duration for each plant was determined by local botany expertise often after consulting the USDA plants database.

This field contains the broader lifeform of a plant either Woody or Non-woody. This is determined by the GrowthHabitSub value. Forb, Graminoid, and Sedge are Non-woody and Succulent, Shrub, SubShrub, and Tree are Woody.

The lifeform of a plant in this dataset. Options are Forb, Graminoid, Sedge, Succulent, Shrub, SubShrub, Tree. The most common growth habit for each plant was determined by local botany expertise often after consulting the USDA plants database.
The identifier of the species list used to calculate indicators.
